question_text: A 49-year-old man is evaluated for a growth on his finger.
question_stem: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
critique: This patient most likely has verruca vulgaris (common warts) (Option D). Verruca vulgaris are skin-colored verrucous papules that are keratotic and exophytic. Thrombosed capillaries manifesting as black dots are seen when the top of the wart is pared down. Other types of warts include verruca plana (flat warts), which are skin-colored, flat-topped papules; condyloma acuminata (genital warts), which are smooth to digitate papules that are skin-colored to tan; and verruca plantaris/palmaris (plantar/palmar warts), which are exo-/endophytic papules with thrombosed capillaries. Warts (verruca and condyloma) are caused by human papillomavirus.
